document.masterDocTitle: The Hydraenidae of Cuba (Insecta: Coleoptera) I: Contribution to the fauna of eastern Cuba

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Hydraenidae of Cuba (Insecta: Coleoptera) I: Contribution to the fauna of eastern Cuba

bibRefCitation.author: Spangler, P. J.
bibRefCitation.refString: Spangler, P. J. (1980) Two new species of aquatic beetles of the genus Hydraena from Cuba (Coleoptera: Hydraenidae). Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington, 82, 329 - 333.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Hydraena perkinsi Spangler, 1980: 331
.—
Perkins, 1980: 172
.—
Spangler, 1981: 162
.—
Jäch et al . 2000: 80
.—
Peck, 2005: 55
.—
Deler-Hernández & Cala-Riquelme, 2010: 73
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis: Habitus as in Fig. 35 . Male terminalia : Ventrite VII ( Fig. 13 ) oval, spiculum gastrale long, relatively wide and straight, firmly attached to ventrite. Terminal tergite ( Fig. 5 ) trapezoidal. Female terminalia : Gonocoxite ( Fig. 25 ) transverse, with outer plate symmetrical; inner plate symmetrical, with a elongate impression, divided in two portions. Last tergite transverse, with a distal row of stout, small setae ( Fig. 26 ). Male genitalia as in Figs. 36–37 . Spermatheca : C-shaped in lateral view; spermathecal duct curved ( Figs. 54–55 ), long and narrow for entire length. For a detailed external description see Perkins (1980: 172) .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 14. Habitus of
Hydraena decui
. Scale = 0.5 mm.

Distribution: Currently only known from Cuba ( Perkins 1980 ).
Hydraena perkinsi
is the most widespread and common species of
Hydraena
in eastern Cuba ( Fig. 58 ).
